What is the output of the following program?


void main() {
    int x = 2, y = 3;
    float z;
    z = ++x + y++;
    printf("%d, %d, %f\n", x, y, z);
}

What is the output of the following program?


void main() {
    int i = 3;
    float f;
    f = i-- + 1.5;
    printf("%d, %f\n", i, f);
}

What will be the output of the following code?


void main() {
    printf("%d\n", sizeof(main));
}

What is the output of the following C program?
int main() {
    int a = 1;
    switch(a) {
        case 1:
            printf("One ");
        case 2:
            printf("Two ");
        default:
            printf("Default");
    }
}

What is the output of the following program?

void main() {
    int x = 5, y = 10;
    printf("%d", x << y);
}

What is the output of the following program?



void main() {
    int *p = (int *)malloc(sizeof(int));
    printf("%lu\n", sizeof(p));
    free(p);
}

What will be the output of the following program?



void main() {
    int *arr;
    arr = (int *)calloc(5, sizeof(int));
    for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
        printf("%d ", arr[i]);
    }
    free(arr);
}

What will be the output of the following program?


union Data {
    int i;
    char c;
};

void main() {
    union Data data;
    data.i = 65;
    printf("%d, %c\n", data.i, data.c);
}

enum Status { OFF, ON, UNKNOWN = -1 };

void main() {
    enum Status s = UNKNOWN;
    printf("%d\n", s);
}
Which command is used to display the last few lines of a text file?

Consider the following code:
class A {
public:
    virtual void display() = 0;
    virtual void show() {
        std::cout << "A::show" << std::endl;
    }
};

class B : public A {
public:
    void display() {
        std::cout << "B::display" << std::endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    B objB;
    objB.display();
    objB.show();

    return 0;
}

What is the output of the above code?

Consider the following code snippet:
class A {
public:
    virtual void func() {
        std::cout << "A::func" << std::endl;
    }
};

class B : public A {
public:
    void func(int x) {
        std::cout << "B::func with int" << std::endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    B objB;
    objB.func();
    objB.func(10);

    return 0;
}

What is the output of the above code?
What does the 'this' pointer refer to in a class?

Consider the following code snippet:
class Animal {
public:
    virtual void makeSound() {
        std::cout << "Animal sound" << std::endl;
    }
};

class Dog : public Animal {
public:
    void makeSound() override {
        std::cout << "Woof" << std::endl;
    }
};

class Cat : public Animal {
public:
    void makeSound() override {
        std::cout << "Meow" << std::endl;
    }
};

void playSound(Animal* a) {
    a->makeSound();
}

int main() {
    Dog d;
    Cat c;
    Animal* arr[2] = { &d, &c };

    for (int i = 0; i < 2; ++i) {
        playSound(arr[i]);
    }

    return 0;
}

What is the output of the above code?

Consider the following code snippet:
class A {
public:
    virtual void func() {
        std::cout << "A::func" << std::endl;
    }
};

class B : public A {
public:
    void func() override {
        std::cout << "B::func" << std::endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    B objB;
    A objA = objB;
    objA.func();

    return 0;
}

What is the output of the above code?

Consider the following code snippet:
class A {
public:
    A() {
        std::cout << "Constructor of A" << std::endl;
    }
};

class B : public A {
public:
    B() {
        std::cout << "Constructor of B" << std::endl;
    }
};

class C : public B {
public:
    C() {
        std::cout << "Constructor of C" << std::endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    C c;

    return 0;
}

What is the output of the above code?

options.a:
Constructor of A
Constructor of B
Constructor of C
options.b:
Constructor of C
Constructor of B
Constructor of A

questions.question:
Consider the following code snippet:
class A {
    int x;
public:
    A(int val) : x(val) {}
    friend void modify(A& obj, int newVal);
};

void modify(A& obj, int newVal) {
    obj.x = newVal;
}

int main() {
    A a(5);
    modify(a, 10);
    std::cout << "New value of x: " << a.x << std::endl;

    return 0;
}

What is the output of the above code?

Consider the following code snippet:
namespace first {
    int x = 5;
    namespace second {
        int y = 10;
    }
}

int main() {
    using namespace first;
    std::cout << x << " " << second::y << std::endl;
    return 0;
}

What is the output of the above code?

Consider the following code snippet:


template <typename T>
void display(T value) {
    std::cout << "ZZZ: " << value << std::endl;
}

template <>
void display<int>(int value) {
    std::cout << "XXX: " << value << std::endl;
}

int main() {
    display(5);
    display(3.14);

    return 0;
}

What is the output of the above code?

What will the following while loop in Bash do?
counter=0
while [ $counter -lt 5 ]; do
    echo "Counter: $counter"
    counter=$((counter+1))
done

Given a table orders(order_id, customer_id, order_date), which SQL statement retrieves the most recent order for each customer?

options.a: SELECT customer_id, MAX(order_date) FROM orders GROUP BY customer_id;
options.b: SELECT DISTINCT customer_id, order_date FROM orders ORDER BY order_date DESC;
options.c: SELECT customer_id, order_date FROM orders WHERE order_date IN (SELECT MAX(order_date) FROM orders GROUP BY customer_id);
options.d: SELECT customer_id, FIRST(order_date) FROM orders GROUP BY customer_id;
